content: @Mara do we have a WIP roadmap doc already?

Regarding making std less special and letting the crate ecosystem build better things... are there any things in the library where we should expose the underlying primitives to improve customization/interop? Similar to raw_fd/raw_handle, pids, as_raw_parts, ...
@Jane Lusby [she/her] nope. i was hoping the meeting notes of today would be the start of that. will try to draft something some time this/next week :)

@The 8472 yeah good question. that's exactly the kind of stuff i think we should be looking at. i think we already do a pretty okay job there. Maybe OsString could allow access to the raw bytes (even if it's in wtf-8 on windows). The as_raw_fd stuff is not great, but the new unstable api with OwnedFd/BorrowedFd improves things lots.

okay, lmk if there's anything I can do to help. I want to make finishing / publishing a 2022 roadmap my immediate top priority then use that document to inform further prioritization. Happy to handle drafting that initial roadmap from the meeting notes if that helps
gonna go ahead and create a scratch doc for now so I have a place to dump thoughts until you've written up a more formal draft
https://hackmd.io/@rust-libs/SyPZFH3kc
I tried to distill out and list all the suggestions people had for directions we could go with the 2022 roadmap
please lmk if I missed anything
I'm also refining the points I suggested a bit and would encourage others to do the same with sections they care about
@Jane Lusby [she/her] That looks great!
There are some minor details I might expand, but I think you've captured a good roadmap outline.

Some concrete thoughts (happy to make these changes but wanted to get your thoughts before just diving into edits on the doc):

  • Under "making the standard library less special" I'd add a couple of sub-items, one that ties that into providing features and infrastructure that other libraries can build on without having to be part of std, and another that ties together with the "cleaner factorization" point.
  • Related, I think "fd-based/Handle-based APIs for directories (e.g. openat)" needs some detail about how those APIs aren't just about the feature themselves, but about infrastructure that enables many other things being built on it.
  • On "Improve process for moving code from popular crates into std", I'd add the detail of "and avoiding ecosystem breakage when doing so, including the library we're adding features from, and crates that depends on that library"

1. :+1:, though for the tie in with the other point I'd put that in the second section for notes on the various goals, I already put a bunch of notes down there on how the various goals could be combined into new superset goals
1. :+1:
1. Feel free to add that clarification now though I had put the Itertools::intersperse mention in an attempt to make that clarification

Jane Lusby [she/her] said:

  1. :+1:, though for the tie in with the other point I'd put that in the second section for notes on the various goals, I already put a bunch of notes down there on how the various goals could be combined into new superset goals

Sounds good to me. That section may also be a good place to mention tie-ins with other team roadmaps.
for now I hope that's good enough for the other libs team members to know what we're talking about but we'd absolutely need to expand on that for any final draft roadmap we intend to publish

Jane Lusby [she/her] said:

  1. Feel free to add that clarification now though I had put the Itertools::intersperse mention in an attempt to make that clarification

Absolutely; I just want to make this accessible to folks who aren't familiar with the details of that particular case.
good call
I've jotted down a few additional points (Allocator, API evolution).

One thing i'd like to see is a source of randomness added in. I want to be clear here, I do not mean a rand like API with generators and ranges and such, I basically mean "finish moving the getrandom crate into std"

Lokathor said:

One thing i'd like to see is a source of randomness added in. I want to be clear here, I do not mean a rand like API with generators and ranges and such, I basically mean "finish moving the getrandom crate into std"

seems like that could be covered by the "growing the standard library" theme
yes it's certainly a bullet point of that theme
added a note
though I would be surprised if piggybacking that on the roadmap would be the best way to get that done
are there active blockers right now or is that just waiting for someone to do the work?

I'm not aware of active blockers for Tier1 targets. Things behave a little funny on wasm32-unknown-unknown because of the uncertain nature of where the wasm is gonna run, which should maybe be resolved somehow.
given how many APIs wasm already implements by just having them panic I would be surprised if that ends up being a barrier

Build-std by default?

Is there any background on this? I have my own reasons for wanting this but I'd like to know what other people think.

Jane Lusby [she/her] said:

given how many APIs wasm already implements by just having them panic I would be surprised if that ends up being a barrier

That's true of -unknown-unknown, but hopefully not of -wasi or future targets.

@Ben Kimock (Saethlin)

  • build with overflow checks or debug asserts
  • ensure that the program is built without some std features (e.g. unicode tables)
  • compile std with specific target-features

Lokathor said:

One thing i'd like to see is a source of randomness added in. I want to be clear here, I do not mean a rand like API with generators and ranges and such, I basically mean "finish moving the getrandom crate into std"

this, this, this. a std::io::Random that implements Read, please!

I want to work on the roadmap some more today and am interested in reframing how approach developing the doc to be more similar to how the compiler team set up their 2022 ambitions document. Instead of coming at this from a "what should our theme be" I think it might be helpful to figure out what our collective current direction is, and identify the theme of our existing motivations. Along those lines I think it might be a useful exercise for each of us to answer the following questions:

  • What work are you interested in doing in the coming year?
  • What work are you interested in mentoring?
  • What work do you think is important / needs doing?
I've gone ahead and updated the roadmap scratch doc https://hackmd.io/UawuryT2SRuJ8GqEjdaQ_g?both to include these questions and am filling out my answers to them within the doc
Also, I noticed that so far only libs/libs-api team members have added individual goals sections, but I think its important that we capture the goals of the libs-contributors members as well
so if you're on libs-contributors please consider filling out a section as well

I would say it is worth also stating what the team thinks is important and would get done if it were possible. Even though people mostly work on what they want because open source, I think it if you can paint a compelling picture of how things could be, that can shape what people want to work on (especially for new contributors). It is also useful for people to prioritise their 'overhead' time, e.g., folk don't have enough time to review everything straight away and tend to do at least some review work on what they think is important in general, not just important for their goals, so being explicit about what the team thinks is important is useful there.

bumping this thread as a reminder to fill in the a section on your individual goals in the scratch document if you haven't already. I think ideally we should aim to pick a theme and general shape of the roadmap based on the scratch document by the end of next week's libs team meetings so we can begin working on a blog post which we can then present in the CTCFT on March 21st
related, here's the lang team roadmap: https://hackmd.io/JGhj3CFJSmuDvpiPxbWaTQ
which is relevant because the lang team is interested in coordinating our roadmaps so its closer to being a lang+libs team roadmap rather than two entirely separate roadmaps

bumping this thread as a reminder to fill in the a section on your individual goals in the scratch document

Thanks! Added my section.
writing the roadmap/update blog post today. i was thinking to make it a combined "here's what happened in the last quarter" and "here's what's on our minds now" kind of thing.
i'll go over PRs and stabilizations of the last three months, but if you have any specific features/changes/stabilizations/.. that you think should be highlighted, please let me know!
cc @T-libs @T-libs-api ^
maybe we can turn this into a habit and do this every quarter. a quick moment to zoom out and look back and what has happened

Mara said:

i'll go over PRs and stabilizations of the last three months, but if you have any specific features/changes/stabilizations/.. that you think should be highlighted, please let me know!

In a call at the moment but will try to list some asynchronously.
